feedStatus.name: No Priors (Elad Gil & Sarah Guo)
newEpisodes: Ep 149 - Dave Baszucki, Roblox CEO: '4D Creation Open Beta: NPCs, 4D Worlds, and the Future of Gaming' (Feb 5, 2026)
mediumPriority: Ep 149 — Baszucki discusses how Roblox leverages AI to create NPCs trained on 13B monthly user hours. Medium priority: touches on AI deployment at scale within a platform company, but more product-focused than structurally focused.

feedStatus.name: BG2 Pod (Gurley & Gerstner)
feedStatus.notes: Unable to confirm any new episodes since Feb 1. Most recent confirmed episode is Dec 23, 2025 (Databricks & Glean AI Enterprise). Search results reference episodes with Michael Dell, OpenAI CPO Kevin Weil, and tariff discussions but without clear dates post-Feb 1. The BG2 site and Apple Podcasts did not return February 2026 episodes.

feedStatus.name: Dwarkesh Podcast
newEpisodes: Elon Musk - 'In 36 months, the cheapest place to put AI will be space' (Feb 5, 2026, ~2h50m)
highPriority: Elon Musk episode — HIGH PRIORITY: Deep-scanned. Contains structural content about xAI organization (several hundred engineers, not researchers), Musk's distinction between xAI as engineering org vs 'AI labs,' and integration questions between xAI/Tesla/SpaceX. Musk declined to discuss xAI-Tesla structural relationships citing public company constraints. Also covers DOGE government restructuring.

feedStatus.name: Latent Space (swyx & Alessio)
newEpisodes: The First Mechanistic Interpretability Frontier Lab — Myra Deng & Mark Bissell, Goodfire AI (Feb 6, 2026, 1h08m)
lowPriority: Goodfire AI episode — technical/product focus on mechanistic interpretability, not organizational structure. Low relevance.

feedStatus.name: Acquired
feedStatus.notes: Most recent episode remains 'The NFL (2026 Update) Special' from Jan 26, 2026. No new episodes in February. An HBR Cold Call episode about scaling the Acquired podcast was published Feb 3 — interesting as a media org case study but not relevant to our research question.

feedStatus.name: Stratechery (Ben Thompson)
newEpisodes: An Interview with Benedict Evans About AI and Software (Feb 5, 2026)
An Interview with Kalshi CEO Tarek Mansour About Prediction Markets (Feb 4-5, 2026)
highPriority: Benedict Evans interview — HIGH PRIORITY: Topics include 'the crisis facing software, the future of the corporation, OpenAI, and the struggle to define the LLM paradigm.' The 'future of the corporation' angle is directly relevant to our structural question. Could not deep-scan due to paywall.

SaaSmageddon and the Super Bowl — HIGH PRIORITY: Covers 'SaaSmageddon and the Future, Microsoft After a Market Correction, and Anthropic's Super Bowl.' The SaaSmageddon narrative has major structural implications for how enterprises reorganize around AI. Could not deep-scan due to paywall.
mediumPriority: Microsoft and Software Survival (Feb 3, 2026) — Previously scanned date but content is new since last check. Discusses which software companies survive in AI era. Could not deep-scan due to paywall.
feedStatus.notes: All Stratechery articles are behind paywall. Search result summaries suggest very high relevance to our research question, especially the Benedict Evans interview on 'the future of the corporation' and the SaaSmageddon coverage. Recommend manual reading with subscription access.

feedStatus.name: One Useful Thing (Ethan Mollick)
newEpisodes: Management as AI Superpower (Jan 27, 2026) — may have been missed in prior scan
highPriority: Management as AI Superpower — HIGH PRIORITY: Deep-scanned. Mollick argues management skills (delegation, scoping, evaluation) are the critical competency for AI work. His MBA experimental class showed that subject matter expertise + clear articulation of requirements matters more than AI expertise. Scarce resource shifts from capable workers to 'clear vision and directive ability.' Directly relevant to organizational structure question: who manages AI, how, and what skills matter.
feedStatus.notes: No new posts confirmed since Jan 27. The 'Which AI to Use Now' guide was updated 2/15 but that is a future date reference — likely refers to ongoing updates. No February 2026 original posts confirmed yet.

feedStatus.name: All-In Podcast
newEpisodes: Ep ~261 - 'Epstein Files, Is SaaS Dead?, Moltbook Panic, SpaceX xAI Merger, Trump's Fed Pick' (Feb 7, 2026)
highPriority: Feb 7 episode — HIGH PRIORITY for two segments: (1) 'Is SaaS Dead?' discussion in context of the SaaSmageddon market crash, and (2) SpaceX-xAI Merger discussion. Both are structurally relevant. The SaaS segment connects to how enterprises restructure software buying as AI agents replace human seats. The SpaceX-xAI merger is the biggest structural move in AI this week.
mediumPriority: Jan 25 episode — CEO interviews (Circle, CrowdStrike, Archer, Crusoe) from Davos. Crusoe CEO Chase Lochmiller on 'powering the trillion-dollar AI buildout' is medium priority for infrastructure/structure angle.

organizations.source: Multiple sources (Yahoo Finance, WebProNews, Inc, Fortune) — Bob Sternfels interviews at CES/Davos Jan 2026
organizations.relevance: HIGH — passes all three relevance tests
structuralFindings: McKinsey now has 60,000 total 'employees': 40,000 humans + 25,000 personalized AI agents
Target: 1:1 ratio of AI agents to human employees by end of 2026
Client-facing roles grew ~25%; non-client-facing roles shrank ~25%
AI agents handle market research, financial modeling, drafting preliminary reports, processing terabytes of data
Saved 1.5 million hours in search and synthesis work in 2025
Productivity gains reaching 30% in certain workflows
Business model shifting from traditional advisory to joint business cases with underwritten outcomes
Three irreplaceable human capabilities identified: creativity, judgment, interpersonal acumen
organizations.structuralModel: AI-augmented consulting: each human consultant paired with AI agent counterpart. Client-facing roles expand, back-office contracts. Classic ambidexterity tension: exploiting existing advisory relationships while exploring AI-native delivery model.
organizations.taxonomyFit: Potential Model 7 (AI-Augmented Workforce) or new model — the 1:1 human-agent pairing at this scale is novel
organizations.specimenPotential: VERY HIGH — McKinsey is both a specimen (how it structures its own AI work) and a meta-case (it advises others on AI structure). The 25K agents / 40K humans ratio is the most concrete organizational metric we've collected.

organizations.relevance: HIGH — passes structural and specificity tests
structuralFindings: SpaceX acquired xAI on Feb 2, 2026 — largest merger in history at $1.25 trillion combined valuation (SpaceX $1T, xAI $250B)
xAI has 'several hundred' employees, per Musk on Dwarkesh podcast (Feb 5)
Musk frames xAI as engineering org, not a 'lab': 'I prefer the word engineer more than I prefer the word researcher'
Musk criticizes other AI companies structured as C-corps/B-corps claiming to be 'labs'
Strategic rationale: orbital AI data centers — space-based compute to solve terrestrial power/cooling constraints
Integration details not publicly disclosed; Musk declined to discuss xAI-Tesla structural relationship on Dwarkesh
Blue Origin and Google's Project Suncatcher pursuing similar space-based AI infrastructure
IPO planned for combined entity — up to $50B raise at $1.5T valuation
organizations.structuralModel: Vertical integration of AI compute + launch capability. Musk consolidating AI exploration (xAI) with infrastructure execution (SpaceX) under single entity. Unlike other tech cos that keep AI as a division, this merges AI as a core competency with physical infrastructure.
organizations.taxonomyFit: Novel — could be Model 1 variant (Dedicated AI Unit absorbed into parent) or new model of vertical AI-infrastructure integration
organizations.specimenPotential: HIGH — the biggest structural move in AI this period. However, organizational details are thin; most reporting focuses on financial terms and strategic rationale, not internal structure.

broaderTrends.title: SaaSmageddon: AI agents trigger $285B software stock crash
broaderTrends.description: On Feb 4, 2026, the Nasdaq Cloud Index plummeted, wiping $285B in value. Trigger: wave of disappointing SaaS earnings + Anthropic's release of AI automation tools demonstrating ability to replace workflows in legal, marketing, customer service. The structural implication: enterprises shifting from seat-based SaaS licensing to AI-agent-based consumption models. IDC predicts by 2028, 70% of software vendors will abandon pure seat-based pricing. This forces enterprises to reorganize around 'end-to-end outcomes rather than application silos.'
broaderTrends.relevanceToResearch: VERY HIGH — this is the macro event that makes our research question urgent. If AI agents replace human software users, organizations must restructure procurement, IT architecture, and process teams. The shift from 'managing human workers who use software' to 'managing AI agents that orchestrate workflows' is a fundamental structural transformation.

broaderTrends.title: Management skills emerging as the critical AI competency
broaderTrends.description: Ethan Mollick's experimental MBA class at Wharton showed that students who succeeded in building AI-powered startups in 4 days were those with management skills (scoping problems, delegating clearly, evaluating output) — not those with AI expertise. The scarce resource shifts from capable workers to 'clear vision and directive ability.' Managers become orchestrators of AI capabilities rather than individual contributors.
broaderTrends.relevanceToResearch: HIGH — directly addresses how organizations should structure human roles around AI. The finding that management > technical AI skill for AI deployment suggests specific structural choices about who leads AI work (domain experts with management skills, not AI specialists).

broaderTrends.title: AI agent-to-human ratios becoming a trackable organizational metric
broaderTrends.description: McKinsey's disclosure of 25,000 AI agents alongside 40,000 human employees establishes a concrete metric: the AI agent-to-human ratio (currently 0.625:1 at McKinsey, targeting 1:1 by year-end). This is the first major professional services firm to publicly report this ratio. Combined with the SaaSmageddon trend (fewer human seats needed), this suggests organizations are approaching a structural tipping point where AI agents are counted as part of the workforce, not just tools.
broaderTrends.relevanceToResearch: HIGH — this is a new structural metric that didn't exist in our taxonomy. Organizations are moving from 'AI as tool' to 'AI as workforce member,' which has profound implications for org charts, resource allocation, and governance.

newSourcesDiscovered.name: The Chief AI Officer Show
newSourcesDiscovered.description: Bridges enterprise buyers and AI innovators through conversations with CAIOs and startup founders. Could be a rich source for structural insights about how organizations create and staff CAIO roles.
newSourcesDiscovered.priority: Medium — worth adding to Tier 2 sources for periodic scanning

newSourcesDiscovered.name: CAIO Connect Podcast
newSourcesDiscovered.description: 58 episodes featuring Chief AI Officers. Hosted by Sanjay Puri. Covers challenges and triumphs of CAIOs.
newSourcesDiscovered.priority: Medium — 58 episodes is a substantial backlog that could contain structural insights

purposeClaimsDiscovered.speaker: Elon Musk
purposeClaimsDiscovered.claimSummary: Musk uses the engineering identity to distinguish xAI from competitors: 'I prefer the word engineer more than I prefer the word researcher. Most of the time, what you're doing is engineering, not coming up with a fundamentally new algorithm.' He also criticizes competitors' identity claims: 'I somewhat disagree with the AI companies that are C-corp or B-corp trying to generate profit as much as possible or revenue as much as possible, saying they're labs. They're not labs.'
purposeClaimsDiscovered.rhetoricalFunction: Identity-based authorization — Musk defines xAI's identity (engineering, not research) to justify structural choices and distinguish from competitors who claim 'lab' status

purposeClaimsDiscovered.speaker: Elon Musk
purposeClaimsDiscovered.context: xAI blog post announcing SpaceX merger, Feb 2, 2026; reiterated in Dwarkesh interview
purposeClaimsDiscovered.claimSummary: Musk frames the SpaceX-xAI merger as solving an existential infrastructure constraint: 'Global electricity demand for AI simply cannot be met with terrestrial solutions, even in the near term, without imposing hardship on communities and the environment.' Also: 'Space-based AI is obviously the only way to scale.'
purposeClaimsDiscovered.rhetoricalFunction: Necessity-based authorization — frames the structural merger as the only viable solution to an existential constraint, making the organizational change appear inevitable rather than strategic

purposeClaimsDiscovered.speaker: Bob Sternfels (Global Managing Partner)
purposeClaimsDiscovered.context: Multiple interviews at CES and Davos, January 2026
purposeClaimsDiscovered.claimSummary: Sternfels frames AI integration around human capability: identifies three irreplaceable human capabilities — 'creativity, judgment, and interpersonal acumen' — and uses this to justify the structural shift where client-facing roles expand while non-client roles contract. The 1:1 human-agent pairing vision is framed as augmentation, not replacement.
purposeClaimsDiscovered.rhetoricalFunction: Values-based authorization — uses human capability framing to authorize a major structural reorganization (25% growth in some roles, 25% cuts in others), making the reorg appear as a talent investment rather than a cost-cutting exercise

actionItems.detail: The Benedict Evans interview on 'the future of the corporation' and the SaaSmageddon coverage are likely our highest-value content this week. Both are paywalled. Recommend reading with subscription access and extracting structural insights manually.
McKinsey's 25K AI agents / 40K humans disclosure with 25% role growth/contraction is the most concrete organizational data point we've collected this cycle. Rich enough for full specimen curation.
The $1.25T merger is the biggest structural AI move of the period, but organizational details are thin. May want to wait for more structural reporting before curating a full specimen.
The DOGE section (timestamped at 02:20:08) was not fully captured in our WebFetch. Government restructuring via DOGE may have structural parallels relevant to our research.
The 'Is SaaS Dead?' segment likely contains investor-perspective structural insights about enterprise reorganization around AI agents.
